Yes, I apologize for the confusion. The "joycontrol" repository you mentioned is a different project that allows you to simulate Joy-Con signals to control the Nintendo Switch.

The joycontrol project works by sending raw Bluetooth HID reports to the Nintendo Switch over a Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) connection. These reports mimic the data that is sent by an actual Joy-Con controller and are used by the Switch to determine which buttons are being pressed and how the sticks are being moved.

Here is a high-level overview of how the joycontrol library works:

1. Scan for the Nintendo Switch over BLE: The library uses the Bluetooth API of the operating system to scan for BLE devices. It looks for a device with a specific Bluetooth address that is known to belong to the Nintendo Switch.
2. Connect to the Switch: Once the Nintendo Switch is found, the library establishes a connection by creating a Bluetooth socket and sending a connection request to the Switch.
